_comment: Operator-grounded test paths derived from KI7MT's 49,233 QSO log (QRZ export), cross-validated against 5.7M contest signatures (234M QSOs). POSITIVE tests are hard gates: the path was actually worked, so the model MUST predict positive SNR. NEGATIVE tests are soft sanity checks: absence of QSOs may reflect operating habits, not physics — except where physics dictates closure (e.g., 10m transatlantic at 2 AM). Parsed using adif-mcp.
_source: ki7mt-qrz.adi (49,233 QSOs, 2009-2025, 271 DXCCs) + contest.signatures (5.7M sigs, 234M QSOs)
_confidence_key: hard = physics dictates result regardless of operating habits; soft = absence may reflect habits, not physics

tests.name: 10m East Coast — Daytime Open
tests.evidence: 97 QSOs DN46→FM19 on 10m, peak at 19z, peak month Dec
tests.physics: F2 skip, solar-illuminated path, high SFI, band wide open

tests.name: 10m East Coast — Night Closure
tests.evidence: 0 QSOs at 03z on 10m in KI7MT log. Contest data: 10m NA→EU at 02-04z = 45 QSOs vs 472K at 14-16z (10,000:1 ratio).
tests.physics: F2 layer collapsed, 28 MHz cannot refract, band dead. Not an operating habit — physics.

tests.name: 10m East Coast — Summer Dead Season
tests.evidence: 0 QSOs on 10m in Jun/Jul in KI7MT log. Contest data: 10m NA→EU Jul = 42 QSOs vs Oct = 299,500 (7,000:1 ratio).
tests.physics: Summer F2 critical frequency too low for 28 MHz skip. Physics, not habits.

tests.name: 10m EU Path — Daytime Open
tests.evidence: 170 EU QSOs on 10m, hours 14-19z, peak Oct-Dec
tests.physics: Transatlantic F2, solar-illuminated, high SFI, classic DX path

tests.name: 10m EU Path — Night Closure (THE ACID TEST)
tests.evidence: 0 EU QSOs on 10m after 19z in KI7MT log. Contest: NA→EU 10m at 02-04z = 45 QSOs total across ALL contests. V22-gamma predicts +3.7σ here.
tests.physics: Both ends in darkness, F2 collapsed, 28 MHz impossible. Ham Radio 101.

tests.name: 10m Japan — Afternoon Open
tests.evidence: 198 JA QSOs on 10m, spread across hours, peak Oct-Dec
tests.physics: Trans-Pacific F2 long path, high SFI, JA morning/MT afternoon

tests.name: 15m Japan — Afternoon Open
tests.evidence: 301 QSOs DN46→PM95 on 15m, peak at 17z, peak month Oct
tests.physics: Trans-Pacific F2, reliable high-band DX path

tests.name: 15m EU Path — Daytime Open
tests.physics: Transatlantic F2, afternoon MT, evening EU, band open

tests.name: 20m EU Path — Daytime Open
tests.evidence: 1,760 EU QSOs on 20m, all hours, peak in winter
tests.physics: 20m workhorse DX band, F2 refraction, reliable year-round

tests.name: 40m Japan — Night Open
tests.evidence: 585 JA QSOs on 40m, hours 5-15z, peak Oct
tests.physics: 40m night path, F2 skip at lower frequency, MT darkness + JA morning

tests.name: 80m Domestic Night — Open
tests.evidence: 69 QSOs DN46→CN87 on 80m, peak at 04z, Nov
tests.physics: 80m NVIS/1-hop skip, mutual darkness, domestic range

tests.name: 80m Domestic Day — Dead
tests.evidence: 5 daytime QSOs on 80m in KI7MT log. Contest: 80m NA domestic at 14-15z = 141 sigs vs 02-04z = 57,207 sigs (400:1 ratio).
tests.physics: D-layer absorption kills 80m in daylight. 5 QSOs in 16 years = physics, not habits.

tests.name: 160m Domestic Night — Open
tests.evidence: 76 QSOs DN46→CN87 on 160m, peak at 04z, Feb
tests.physics: 160m requires mutual darkness, winter nights, low D-layer absorption

tests.name: 160m Domestic Day — Dead
tests.evidence: 0 QSOs 16-20z on 160m in KI7MT log. Contest: 160m NA domestic at 13-20z = 11 sigs vs 00-05z = 16,878 sigs (1,500:1 ratio).
tests.physics: Complete D-layer absorption at 1.8 MHz in daylight. Physics, not habits.

tests.name: 160m Japan — Deep Night DX
tests.evidence: 43 JA QSOs on 160m, hours 9-15z, Jan peak. Rare but real.
tests.physics: 160m trans-Pacific, mutual darkness window, low Kp critical

tests.name: 160m Summer — Dead Season
tests.evidence: 0 QSOs on 160m in Mar-Oct. Likely physics (short nights, high noise) but operator may not have had 160m antenna year-round.
tests.physics: Summer nights too short for 160m propagation, atmospheric noise dominant. Possibly also antenna/operating habits.

tests.name: Band Order — Day (high > low)
tests.physics: High bands dominate in daylight (F2 ionization). Low bands absorbed (D-layer).

tests.name: Band Order — Night (low > high)
tests.physics: Low bands dominate at night (no D-layer, F2 still present for NVIS). High bands dead.
